children.name: set
children.definition: (of the sun, moon or planets) to go down below the horizon (= the line at which the Earth seems to join the sky): lặn
examples: The sun usually sets at about 6pm at this time of year.
The setting sun cast a deep red glow over the city’s rosy stone.
We sat on the beach and watched the sun set.
The setting sun cast long shadows across the lawn.

children.name: go down
children.definition: if the sun goes down, it moves downwards in the sky until it cannot be seen: lặn
examples: We sat on the balcony and watched the sun go down.
On summer evenings we would sit on the verandah and watch the sun go down.

children.name: sink
children.definition: if the sun sinks, it goes down slowly - used especially in descriptions or stories: lặn
examples: The sun sank and darkness fell on the island.As the sun sank lower and lower, the sky first turned pink and then orange

children.name: observatory
children.definition: a building from which scientists can watch the planets, the stars, the weather, etc.: đài thiên văn, đài quan sát

children.name: astronomy
children.definition: the scientific study of the universe and of objects which exist naturally in space, such as the moon, the sun, planets and stars: thiên văn học
examples: astronomical[attri adj] connected with astronomy
the Royal Astronomical Society astronomical observations/instruments
astronomically[adv]in a way that is connected with astronomy
The satellite will observe objects that are particularly interesting astronomically.

children.name: orbit
children.definition: the curved path through which objects in space move around a planet or star: quỹ đạo
examples: The satellite is nowina stable orbit.
Once in space, the spacecraft willgo intoorbitaroundthe Earth.
orbit[I or T] to follow a curved path around a planet or star: quay quanh, di chuyển theo quỹ đạo
On this mission the Shuttle will orbit (the Earth) at a height of several hundred miles.
orbital[adj]
an orbital space station

children.name: the solar system
children.definition: the sun and the group of planets which move around it: hệ mặt trời

children.name: meteor/shooting star/falling star
children.definition: a piece of rock or other matter from space that produces a bright light as it travels through the Earth's atmosphere: sao băng
examples: Astronomers track large meteors using radar.
ameteor shower(= a lot of meteors that fall down towards the Earth at the same time )
meteoric[adj] relating to or caused by a meteor
The sudden flash of light in the night sky was caused by a meteoric fireball.

children.name: meteorite
children.definition: a piece of rock or other matter from space that has landed on Earth: đá trời; thiên thạch

children.name: comet
children.definition: an object like a bright ball with a long tail that moves around the sun, usually at a great distance from it, that is seen on rare occasions from Earth as a bright line in the sky: sao chổi
examples: Halley’s comet

children.name: moon
children.definition: a similar round object that moves around another planet
examples: Jupiter has at least sixteen moons.

children.name: asteroid
children.definition: a mass of rock that moves around the sun. Most asteroidsare found between Jupiter and Mars:
examples: the asteroid belt

children.name: rise
children.definition: if the sun or the moonrises,it goes above the level of the horizon or it goes further up into the sky: mọc,lên cao
examples: A full moon rose over the valley.
What time does the sun rise tomorrow morning?
The moon rises nearly an hour later each night.
By midday the sun had risen high in the sky and was burning down on us.

children.name: come up
children.definition: if the sun or the mooncomes up, it moves above the level of thehorizon: mọc lên
examples: The moon came up slowly over the pine trees.
The sun was coming up and you could just see the tops of the mountains.

children.name: the moon
children.definition: / the Moon the round object that you can see shining in the sky at night, and that moves around the Earth every 28 days:

children.name: the moon shines
examples: The moon shone through the window.

children.name: the moon rises
children.definition: alsothe moon comes up
examples: He watched the full moon come up over the trees.

children.name: the moon appears
examples: The moon appeared from behind a cloud.

children.name: the moon comes out
children.definition: appears as it gets dark or a cloud moves
examples: The moon came out from behind the clouds.

children.name: the moon hangs somewhereliterary
children.definition: stays there for a long time
examples: The moon hung over the quiet sea.

children.name: the moon sets
children.definition: goes down so that you cannot see it
examples: The moon had set, but the sky was clear.

children.name: the moon waxes
children.definition: gets bigger each night
examples: The moon waxed larger over the next few days.

children.name: the moon wanes
children.definition: gets smaller each night
examples: The August moon was waning.

children.name: the light of the moon
examples: The clouds blocked out the light of the moon.

children.name: the craters on the surface of the moon
examples: The Americans landed on the Moon in 1969.

children.name: planet
children.definition: a very large round object in space that moves around the Sun or another star: hành tinh
examples: Mercury is the smallest of all the planets.
the planet Earth/ Venus etc
the future of planet Earth
on a planet
Is there life on other planets?
Might there be intelligent life on other planets?
planetary[attri adj]
the planetary system
planetary science/motion

children.name: star
children.definition: a very large ball of burning gas in space, especially one seen from Earth as a point of light in the sky at night: ngôi sao, tinh tú
examples: I lay on my back and looked up at the stars.
The sky was filled with stars.
brightthe brightest star in the night sky
sitting around a campfire under the stars

children.name: faint
examples: The star is faint but visible.

children.name: a distant star
children.definition: very far away
examples: He stared up towards the distant stars.

children.name: a star shines
examples: I looked up and saw hundreds of stars shining in the sky.

children.name: a star twinkles
children.definition: shines with an unsteady light
examples: Stars began to twinkle in the darkening night sky.

children.name: stars appear/come out
children.definition: appear in the sky
examples: We arrived home just as the stars were coming out.

children.name: the stars are out
children.definition: they are shining
examples: There was a full moon, and the stars were out. Thestarswere allout

children.name: a cluster of stars
children.definition: a small group of stars close together in the sky
examples: He fixed his telescope on a tiny little cluster of stars in the constellation of Taurus.

children.name: under the stars
children.definition: outdoors at night

children.name: look up at the stars
examples: I had spent a lot of time looking up at the stars as a kid.

children.name: sleep under the stars
children.definition: in a place with no roof
examples: In the desert, they slept out under the stars.

children.name: solar
children.definition: 1relating to the sun →lunar:

children.name: a solar eclipse
examples: 2using the power of the sun’s light and heat :

children.name: lunar
children.definition: of or relating to the moon
examples: studies of the lunar surface
a lunar eclipse

children.name: moon
children.definition: the appearance or shape of the moon at a particular time:
examples: a clear night with a bright moon
a thin crescent moon
It was the night of thefull moon.

children.name: bright
examples: The moon was very bright.

children.name: a full moon
children.definition: with a completely round shape
examples: A full moon hung low in the sky.

children.name: a half moon
children.definition: looking like half a circle
examples: A half moon was up now, pale and cool.

children.name: a crescent moon
children.definition: with a thin curved shape
examples: The stars and thin crescent moon gave just enough light to see the path.

children.name: a new moon
children.definition: a very thin moon which is just starting to get bigger
examples: trăng nonIt was twilight and a new moon was rising.

children.name: a silver/yellow moon
examples: It was a frosty night, with a cold silver moon.

children.name: a pale moon
examples: Her face glowed in the light of the pale moon.

children.name: a harvest moon
children.definition: the full moon that appears in late September or early October
examples: Over the potato fields a harvest moon was rising.

children.name: there is no moon
examples: There was no moon, and the fields were completely dark.

children.name: black hole
children.definition: a region in space wheregravityis so strong that nothing, not even light, can escape: hố đen

children.name: eclipse
children.definition: when the sun disappears from view, either completely or partly, while the moon is moving between it and the Earth, or when the moon becomes darker while the shadow of the Earth moves over it: thiên thực (nhật thực, nguyệt thực)
examples: On Wednesday there will be atotal/partialeclipseofthe sun.

children.name: a solar eclipse/ an eclipse of the Sun
children.definition: one in which the Sun is hidden behind the Moon
examples: nhật thựcYou need to wear protective glasses to view a solar eclipse.

children.name: a lunar eclipse/an eclipse of the
examples: Moon) (= one in which the Moon is hidden behind the Sun) nguyệt thựcIf it's cloudy, it may not be possible to see the lunar eclipse.

children.name: a partial eclipse
children.definition: one in which the Sun or Moon is not completely hidden
examples: A partial eclipse of the Sun will occur on August 28th.

children.name: a total eclipse
children.definition: one in which the Sun or Moon is completely hidden
examples: The best places to witness the Sun's total eclipse are in southern Africa and South America.

children.name: corona
children.definition: a circle of light that can sometimes be seen around the moon at night, or around the sun during an eclipse (= a situation when the moon is positioned exactly between the sun and the Earth): quầng, hào quang
